messages.content: That's the most weird thing

Note taken. There is always some losers and winners, whatever we would do. Back in the day, we were mining, and we have a lot of first-hand experience gained from that. However, we had to act on this occasion quite seriously and develop an extended package that would put some cap on playing with volumes without any sense, as this would not be practical in real markets either. And we are going to push this into more realistic direction with more market impact, like in the real markets (if not considering the highest liquidity pairs). It was always the intent that high volumes have to be executed smartly, and that will also be playing a role in how different algorithms are going to compare. The only reason why that has not really happened yet is that it does require more in depth time with the LOB dynamics creation. But we also advise to look into that. We have also advised to look into the special order types that we have been pushing out lately, they can (or not) give an edge, when used well. Those would not expose to the same kind of risks as, say, the simplest order types. Also, previously, we had a requirement that you must trade a certain amount, but that was played away by just mindless volume. 

The only way we think is suitable, and is consistent with real markets if the description I gave above. 

And overall, although some have lost "unfairly," we feel the advantage from now is definitely in the corner of those that spend the time and energy to really try to compete well, and not, say, just play a registering game. As this was brought to our attention already some weeks ago, we started to design a system that would help to prevent that. If we were to announce such much before, those actors might as well just prepare accordingly, and the registering game would continue more easily. In essense, we have tried our best to protect the best miners, or those with intent to do really great stuff in this subnet. We value those entities, and would of course like to hear their feedback on the current situation.

Estimated next Wednesday, we may release other updates on these things, but if things do not progress badly, we would not expect any critical changes, more like fine-tuning of things. But please always be a bit prepared, especially if you already are aware that criticism has been expressed, and changes have been requested. We take those quite seriously, and the only reason why this took so much time from our side was that we started to do a big package and not small steps, in particular because we wanted to have a full-blown "better incentive scheme" that has features that all support the best miners, or those that want to be such. We know this may in some cases drop the ball from those that already try to do that, we have experienced the same back in the day, but like then, we feel it was quite necessary. In the bit longer run, there is no question in our view that it is in the best interest of the best miners to do this.

Also note that some of the changes, in such a big package, had to be planned and decided very late in the game, because the complexity is already quite high, with C++ also being slower to develop than Py.

Notice that there is one crucial bit of specialty in our system. This is that when the incentive mechanism has been fine-tuned to be good and working, and we have reached a level of practical relevance with our research related upgrades, including the already launched futures market integration – making it a hybrid simulation – the number of simultaneous simulations will work towards the actually best miners and algorithms. Why is this so? Because it will make the results more reliable, statistically speaking, and while we now provide 20 such simulations, I can already say the next upgrades will be taking this north, much north of that number. We have also intentionally wanted to make the incentive upgrades before such technolical leaps, because otherwise it would not create the desired effect. That means that "luck" plays less and less of a role. We would think this is in the advantage of the best of the best. To get to this point, we are working hard every week to think about the actual execution of the schemes, their potential weaknesses and strenghts. Still, much of the time also goes into technical implementation of efficiency, as it is not an easy thing to do work in C++. This has also caused us longer development cycles in the past, but once we get into the really good stuff, then we promise this will start to bring the fruit. While this technical thing may not yet be apparent to the miners, this should not go unnoticed either. Also there is a bag of tricks we have not used yet, perhaps only hinted at, and we want to use those feats somewhat sparingly to make this one of the best Sns out there. Patience, a bit, we ask — we are on a path that can be a significant one. We ourselves have had the patience of one year in the making from a technological perspective, and over 20 years in the research realm. Being of this level of complexity, with deadlines that matter, this is no easy feat, and we are gaining experience by monitoring and through your valuable feedback.

To ”protect" those with good intentions but accidentally hitting their own orders, we now in the latest upgrade enforced the STP functionality, which is in practice enforced in all regulated exchanges, but not "mandatorily" so as one would expect the trader side to make sure they do not wash trade themselves. Here, we wanted to turn it on by default, and enforce, so that unexpectedly high trading volumes would not occur accidentally, and therefore hit the limit earlier. Those that still trade a lot, without hitting their own orders, yes they would be affected. I can say we are monitoring matters in this regard, and planning for different routes to be taken in different scenarios. If you have been given capital of, say, "100,000" then turning that imes over 10x is quite significant, at least we would regard so, as we are not yet in the ”HFT realm” of market making where very significant trading volumes can be created in a day. This and risk-averseness, as stated in our "subtitle of the subnet," lead us also into this. Once the market impact will be more significant, the best algorithms will, in our research agenda at least, float to the top and stay there.

Thank your explain.
I have one question.
The simulation's cycle is set to 1 day, and it's been 30 hours now and the simulation is still in progress. How to understand about that?
Please check 5EWwdZB7qCCMaAso5Mzcks4UUcPxKYvpAj32t5Mg1v6HSxoF.
Each run is 24H of _simulation time_, see the clock at the top of the page on  [taos.simulate.trading](https://taos.simulate.trading)

For the next week, after this week's (Paris Proof of Talk week) big push with two significant upgrades, we will be making smaller changes and those will be described "descriptively" as early as we have them. Notice that some of these stuff just cannot be announced much earlier, since we work on to the last minute often to define them, and/or test them. It is definitely not true we would not like to release that information in advance, but it is a fact that some of these complexities are actual "complexities."

In any case, we welcome any feedback and should make really great progress in June to get to a level where we initially wanted to be, and now that it should give us more time to communicate and do promotion as well, more blog-posts and articles will be written about our views. I will personally be writing some of those, and some of them will be written in collaboration. Also, there will be discussions ongoing with outside institutions and entities that may have natural interest in this subnet.

Thanks to everybody for the hectic but super-interesting week!
Thank your explain.

@taos・79 We were yesterday informed of certain congestion problems. After much investigation into it, our team could not (yet, at least) find a clear problem at our end. The likely cause we find is insufficient resources on the miner side, especially with regards of decompression of incoming synapses (see above) – this appears to have been the reason at least in some of the cases we have discussed with. Should you find other problems, please do let us know, as our goal is to get this things running "perfectly," especially in the light of the future (maybe already this coming week) increase of simulations (very significantly). Those updates might not be made unless we are somewhat certain that this above indeed is the case. Also, as the subnet targets to get into HFT realm, where the resource requirements would be higher (refer to our white paper on those projections, and how much complexity we are talking about there) we naturally do our best to keep things in check before we venture into that realm. We understand it is important for all. Certainly, at least from my part of research and statistical significance of the results, certain computational requirements will be necessary.  What we attempt to reach for in this subnet is technical, and computationally intensive (which is partly why we are doing this on Bittensor network), and since there are many (increasing number of) simulations and complex order-types, plus a limit-order-book (up to a certain depth), this is good to keep in mind.

It is possible the parameters of this will be changed, as mentioned last week. You can use the Testnet to test strategies before going live, we have given the ID for that. Last week's effort was massive from our end, this week will be more like some fine-tuning of parameters, unless we decide to release more simulations concurrently, as mentioned. The "penalty" over a certain limit can be easily avoided by leaving space for trading volume. The reason why this was placed was discussed, but should add that it creates an optimization problem "when to trade," so that there isn't mindless "I will leave all my asset hanging around in the LOB" or "push the price up by all-in bets." This kind of careless tactics would not exist in the real world either under risk-averseness. But sure, we are likely to tune this parameter set somehow, this was already decided last week in our team meetings that some parameter adjustment is likely here, but whether it is 10x or whatever, there is likely to stay one.

Secondly, you mention of execution quality. I am not sure how experienced you are in this kind of trading game, or actual trading, but we also included in the last two tweeks, deliberately and according to all plans, so-called advanced order-types. These order-types were introduced to help to speed things up, while in the longer-run, as mentioned, we are heading towards the HFT realm with faster reaction times. The fact that there are other agents, possibly using such types, and the background agents that act faster, the so-called HFT Agents, makes it possible that the prices moves from the current levels before you hit them. This, in the current setup, simulates the fact that some of the actors have faster connection, and the fact that the AI Agents would have delay in their processing, as explained in the white paper (due to the presumed use of AI techniques, in its latency).

For testing, we test as much as possible, but last week's package was simply "must do," since as also explained a few times, the previous incentive scheme was under fire, and for a good reason; the previous market was too efficient, or in other words, it was hard to find pockets of inefficiency to beat the market, or the others in the game. This lead to a situation that nearly everybody got similar results, and this was reported, and since we could not start to see a spread between the performances, we started to build a package with many interconnected incentives and mechanisms (some of them punishing). In such a big package, some things will have to be going live without weeks of testing, simply because some of the matters depend on how the AI Agents perform – we do not know a prior what the miners will be doing.

We have stated what we will be doing this week, last week's package was big as was mentioned, also a few days earlier – and it was clear the incentive mechanism was going to be changed. Whether we change something dramatically this week or not, no, do not see any evidence from incentive scheme perspective that would require massive overhaul, but there will be incentive scheme parameter changes likely, which we are reviewing currently, and started to do immediately after the last version went out, when we saw the AI Agents (miners) reactions and potential strategy classes used. Our reactions are always partly dependent on what is going on from the miner side, as we cannot possibly know what they will be doing before release.

Secondly, real markets are dynamic. We have done both HFT, market-making, and speculative trading. This would span decades already in some format or another, and in the crypto realm also since 2015. These markets are extremely volatile and dangerous to trade in. Although our intent is not to create such hassle here, it is a fact that markets are dynamic and the game also changes over time, with institutions and funds entering and withdrawing from the markets. So, dynamic adjustment will anyhow be necessary, and we are getting only started to get to the real problems of the markets, including the deep LOB dynamics, gaps in the LOB, resiliency problems, and bubbles and bursts. These will all require to some extent "live testing."

It is basically a laboratory setting. We started (the subnet) 1-2 months ago in a field that is extremely challenging to model the whole structure of the market. This has never been done, anywhere, academically, and if privately done by some entity or company, it has not been revealed. Although we have about 10 people onboard, and years of experience in trading and also in Bittensor for a significant amount of time, from different perspectives, it remains a challenge to push realistic and yet correctly incentivizing features into such space, because we are giving "initial capital" to use, for free basically (you can count in the registration fee by the protocol) and the incentivize correctly agents that do not behave necessarily in the fashion like they would in real markets. This then requires another layer of thinking how the agents possibly will be behaving, to a large degree.

And that, those reactions, plus the technical difficulty level we do this all at, with C++ programming that seems to be totally unique in this chain to this date, means that we have many things to consider, and cannot proceed with just Python logic and testing into live. The learning curve is longer and steeper, and slowed down because of the technical limitations of the chain, which we will be testing to the limit, so in that sense yes I do believe this subnet is taking risks and chances with those who are onboard whether they want to partake in a subnet pushing boundaries, or whether they just remain relatively stagnant in some other subnet of easier entry barrier. But of course, if we make a mistake, which is possible in some pushes, we try our best to correct for them if we just see the evidence of that and can clearly identify the reason. So, feedback is valuable.
Thanks, our team will review all possible evidence of problems. Will get back on these

Processing is not the only contributor to the time taken to respond; miner has to download the message, decompress, process, compress the instructions and return the response.  Continuing to examine  if there are efficiency gains that can be had at general level in any of these steps.

This does not block any requests, it just ensures that the background processes are completed before proceeding with new queries so that there is no possibility of conflicting access to common variables and these processes cannot interfere with the querying.  The loop condition is never triggered at our validator, the background processes are always completed before this code is reached.

Yes, we are discussing this, and most likely will not put in forward the 1000 simulations this week, even though we might even be able to do 5000 of them already. It might be 100. Or it might be that we postpone that by one week.

We can only do good for the project to push better and better features and applications. We focus on that, and leave the rest to others. We are here to make the greatest "product" of the ecosystem. If that takes time for entities to figure out, so be it then. Also, complaints about the state of incentives help us to make progress, if they are valid. But then again, false interpretations should be also avoided, as there is now already much complexity. Complexity is in itself not "valuable" before it serves well the community, but we know what features will take this to be valuable (inherently). We know because of our previous experience in trading and research. Now, if we stop our progress before we are in the good realm we want to be at, that would not help that aspect either, we cannot get the end-product out. So, there has to be some progress we have planned for, and we have a great array of them coming up.

But I do get your point here, but rest assured, last week was a big update we had to do, now we progress in "smaller steps."

Agent 235, as far as I can see, has fewer timeouts toward 5EWwdZB, but toward the other validators, it has at least 95 timeouts. That's exactly what we're reporting to you — total inconsistency. If a miner manages to get through to one validator, then it works (though still with some timeouts), but if it doesn't — good luck. There's no logic at all. Out of my 7 miners, 6 are getting through somehow, and the seventh can't even move.

On my end, my machine — an R7 2700X with my internet connection (fiber, 1 Gbps) — receives the packet in max 0.25s (measured), decompresses it in max 0.1s (measured), processes it in 0.001s max, repacks it in 0.02s, and starts sending it back, yet gets a timeout 99.9% of the time. That’s all well under 5 seconds.

Meanwhile, I have 2 servers on the other side of the world... One with 2 cores and 2 GB RAM works great with 5EWwdZB but doesn’t move at all with the other validators. Another server in the same location with 4 cores and 8 GB RAM (faster CPU) performs terribly with 5EWwdZB.But on the other hand, toward 5DhTjxp — which is literally on the other side of the world based on IP location and latency — it has significantly fewer timeouts.

When I look at everything, add it up and subtract, the suggestion to increase my network speed and computing power honestly insults my intelligence.

Even though I might be a bit rusty with programming (though with all the tools and AI, I think I’m handling this quite well), with 25 years of experience in maintaining and designing computer systems and my university degree, I’d like to believe I know how to detect a bottleneck.

If you need help with diagnosing the issue, I’m at your disposal.
Thanks, we are still looking, I think up to something now, we will report back asap

@taos・79  ☯️  After _much_ digging, we eventually isolated the reason for higher-than-expected timeout rates by miners to an apparent problem in handling simultaneous connection to all axons in a single call via the usual `bittensor` package query mechanism - in this case, long delays arise during forming of a connection to miners; this phase of the communication is also included in the timeout enforcement, leading to inaccurate measurements of the response times.  

The exact reason for the connection delays here is still under investigation (we have tested with changes to networking config and with increases in available resources), and we will be in touch with the developers for a fuller understanding once we have completed our own dive, but **have now pushed an update which modifies the manner in which the queries are executed so as to evade this issue and ensure accuracy of response times for each UID**.  

Since this method does however lead to a longer overall processing time for all queries, we have also made the adjustment that **each miner will receive a state update synapse that contains only the `accounts` and `notices` data relevant to themselves**.

Under this new mechanism, the processing time captured by the validator reflects only the time taken for the miner to respond, and thus **the timeout parameter has been significantly reduced to 1.0 second**.  This is also necessary to ensure that the total time taken to complete all queries remains reasonable.  We have been testing this at our validator for a short time prior to this announcement, and seeing the majority of miners responding within the timeout at each step.  We will continue to monitor and will adjust this parameter if seen to be necessary.

**Validators**
The update will be automatically pulled and deployed at start of the next simulation hour; to deploy immediately, please execute `git pull && pm2 restart validator`

**Miners**
No changes needed; if you were using account balances or notices from other UIDs than your own in your strategy, you will no longer be able to do so, but the structure of the synapse remains unchanged so that this does not necessitate any updates otherwise.
Please monitor and let us know if you are still experiencing issues with excessive timeouts after confirming your local processing times do not exceed or significantly contribute to your response time.

@taos・79 ☯️  As mentioned, this week's update focuses primarily on optimization with the goal of enabling to speed up simulation progression, and allowing for increases to the book count:

- **Simulator Optimization** : The simulator parallelism implementation have been reworked to make maximal use of the available resources and avoid excessive concurrency overhead present in the previous version; the simulator is now quite capable of maintaining hundreds if not thousands of simulated orderbooks with reasonable speed of progression on the same modest hardware currently in use by our validator. 
- **Validator Optimizations** : All aspects of the query process have been examined in detail and optimized where possible; this includes networking parameter enhancements, extensive benchmarking and resulting improvements to message compression process, minification of the state update message subfields, as well as refinements to the score calculations.  The query processing still presents a bottleneck in terms of the overall simulation time, but is substantially improved such that overall progression rate will increase while miners and validators should experience significant reduction in network traffic, with faster response times also expected to be possible.  Further improvements are necessary to achieve our ultimate goal of 1000s of books, but this step should already allow for significantly more books to be sufficiently handled.
- **Book Count Increase** : The initial increase in book count is **a small bump from 20 to 24 books** so as to allow to monitor the stability and performance of the enhanced setup and avoid introducing significant extra burdens immediately.  Once we have been able to observe the performance in live environment, decisions will be made as to when and in what amount the count will be increased in subsequent releases.
- **Background Model Tweaks** : Just a few minor tweaks to the parameters of the background model are applied with the aim of increasing diversity of behaviour in response to the external signals between different books.

@taos・79 ☯️   This week's update introduces primarily several changes to the incentive mechanism and simulator agent parameters, aimed as always at better motivating intelligent, risk-averse and active trading strategies:

- **Reward Distribution** : The assignment of scores to miners has been modified to increase the incentive allocated to top performing miners while reducing the rewards earned by average and lower performing UIDs.  This is necessary to foster a more competitive environment and avoid distributing emissions to miners who do not seriously attempt to achieve top performance.
- **Outlier Penalty Reduction** : The penalty applied to miner scores where they have very poor performance in one or more books relative to the others is reduced to 67% of the current penalty.
- **FuturesAgent Template** : An additional simple agent strategy template is included which incorporates the same external signal used to guide the direction of the simulated markets in its decision-making.  This real-world connection was intended to provide a clear path to making valid price predictions in the simulated market; this template illustrates in a very simple form how this might be achieved.  We encourage all miners to examine and test this strategy, and expect that the competition for top position would be between miners who most cleverly extend this template to maximize their Sharpe ratios and trading volumes, and those who innovate alternate ways to take advantage of this presumed predictability by capitalizing on other miners' movements.
- **Book Count Increase** : Number of books will be increased from 24 to **32**.
- **Fee Elimination** : In this upcoming simulation, **fees will be set to zero** for all agents in order to eliminate the transaction costs as a potential reason for agents to avoid more active trading strategies, and to reduce the level of difficulty in attaining positive risk adjusted performance.
- **Volume Cap Increase** : The maximum volume allowed to be traded in a 24H window is increased from 10x the initial capital to **20x** initial capital.
- **Active Order Limitation** : The maximum number of orders that an agent may keep open on any given book at one time will be limited to **100**.  This is applied initially to ensure that extremely large numbers of open orders are not accumulated as this can affect the perfomance of simulator and increase traffic and processing time for miner queries, and may be decreased further in later releases so as to also encourage more active order management and prevent lazy overly-passive strategies from being deployed.
- **Background Model Tweaks** : A few adjustments to the parameters of the background model are applied with the aim of strengthening the market reaction to the external price signal and increasing the likelihood and magnitude of background agents' attempts to take advantage of more volatile market conditions.

**These updates will be pushed at ~15:00 UTC today.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~2H following the push.

In the description, we will be later this week motivating things more. I did already give a description above (earlier), plus more will be written in July and published in different formats. Finally, we would be getting into the more serious AI development side, first we just need to get certain incentives correct.

At this point, notice that the rewards distribution is actually following a statistical rule known as the Pareto Rule (20-80 Rule). This rule has already been applied in a different context in our codebase, and it is a very well-known statistical finding especially concerning the distribution of wealth in economy.

Pareto Rule is a power-law, with heavy tails. This means that the distribution drops quite quickly, faster than an exponential would, but leaves heavier tails. In fact, these distributions don't have variance defined, and in some cases not even the mean. That means there is a lot of dispersion. That said, 20 % of the people get 80 % of the wealth – here the rewards.

We believe this all will be get super-interesting when the serious AI development is ongoing, with potential collaboration with other subnets, and pushing the boundary in speed and intelligence. If you haven't yet tried such approaches, it might be a good idea to get started, as some of the hints are given in the white paper, and several more will be given in the forthcoming posts.

@taos・79 Some suggestions based on the most recent update:

We have taken out the transaction costs in order to invite more trading volume, which may have been blocked in the fear of making the wrong decision, thus ending up in the red with bad Sharpe, and volume weighting. Therefore, fee structure has been zeroed for now, before AI templates will be available and other common type of approaches are seen to be applied.

Based on our monitoring, we also wanted to lessen the penalty in the "left-hand tail," of Sharpe Ratio, meaning that getting a bad Sharpe would not yet make it impossible to compete with those that are not taking the chances. We may adjust this later on, but for now, we wanted to lessen the impact of those potentially bad Sharpes that occur every now and then.

Thirdly, as we have observed that some of the opportunites in the market have not been attempted to be taken advantage of, we decided to launch a template algorithm that would clearly indicate some statistical arbitrage opportunity, or at least for now such exists, assuming not too many would do exactly the same. This is just a simple template.

Obviously, more templates are in the plans, and we are pushing towards releasing "AI" template that may already come out next week (Wed), and that should allow more and more opportunities to be found. And then, we will concentrate on the market dynamics, and potentially releasing a few more templates if need be. This is to advise on "what potentially to do."

We will also release what you might call "trading README" that concentrates on what the reasoning is behind the incentive scheme, and what type of things could be done, at least from our "generic perspective" (we are not going to give details) – all that would be done to help more diversity to take place and invite more serious competition based on AI.

This week's goal as explained in the messages above is to get those that find edge to gain more rewards, and conversely, those that would not seek such edge not perform as well. This direction was based on several discussions we had also with other people running similar things in the ecosystem – although we took a less radical road in this respect.

The volume weighting has stayed in there, although it could be put even more weight next week, of course depending on what would be observed. The goal of the volume weighting of Sharpe was discussed quite a lot previously already, so not going to go there for now, but the intent is obviously to get the "good volume" to be rewarded, and "bad volume" penalized.

We did not push for the extra weighting yet, since we put out the template for one typical approach, which can clearly change some of the strategies, or hopefully used as a building block, or risk management tool. At the same time, based on monitoring, we changed some of the parameters of the "background agents" (that do part of the LOB) to reflect this change.

The goal is to move towards more AI-dependent algorithms, and we therefore increase the number of LOBs (simulations) prudently, now going just above 30. The next steps may be to go 2* each week up to about 1000, but it will remained to be seen whether there are resource considerations that will put some breaks on this development or not.

Overall, we want to help to build those algorithms to be better, since our analysis suggests that the competition is not out there to the extent we would hope for. Our observations suggest that volume is not yet appreciated enough, and we pumped up the previous 10x (upper limit related to initial capital given) to 20x. This is also to alleviate stress on "trading too much."

Next week may see some corrections to this scheme, based on the evidence we will see, but we simply could not keep the current system intact, since it was not creating quite realistic type of trading scenarios. We try to help to create algorithms that would fit in the longer run goal of the subnet, based on AI and "deep" HFT.

Well, I am sorry if this is not pleasing, but tried to explain quite a bit the reasoning. Also, this is not only based on our own suggestions and directions, but coming from a wider range of experiences (across subnets overall). We could of course show some statistics and observations, and we can put some screenshots and images for people to review, and indeed we can also open up a platform for miners to observe a few matters on their own (unless they are happy with their own monitoring). Surely, we have also much deeper analysis done, but we can tomorrow and Friday share some more thoughts on this.

Whether the discussion in the day before and today is not sufficient or not, we are going to write and releases blog-posts, articles, and posts on the matters that are relevant here. I think one of the key things we are likely to do, and already decided to do (a long time ago) was templates of algorithms, and drive the innovations and applications towards "AI" (whether that is a broad concept or not, anyhow some people regard ML/DL as such). Our honest intent is to help diversity to grow and help more people to come about, and also do that transparently, so one can evaluate whether to use those templates or not.

We do not advise in such blind application, of course, so if somebody creates better stuff, they are more than welcome. But our observations lead us to believe the algorithms are not taking advantage of certain matters obvious in the data, and that said, also those guys at the top should be then more rewarded. If we cannot get those best guys to be rewarded enough, they are likely not going to develop them enough. There is no point of then rewarding average performance. Yes, we agree and understand that this phase can dramatically create "unstability" before really good approaches are executed.

We take all that evidence in and analyze what you say, and genuinely saying that. We do review the stuff that is going on, and what we have been seeing in the past is very small trading volumes without genuine attempt to risk manage, except with making almost no sensible actions. This would not be considered to be sound risk management to "lay low" and let others to take the risks. True, if somebody accidentally or by skill hit a good spot, they would be rewarded, and we have to review if this would be too unstable, and then we make it more stable. But stability is about not making trades and attempt to risk manage, at least not in the fashion we have envisioned the long-term goal of this net, which is the "AI advised deep HFT." To that direction, whether it is "deep market making" or "deep statistical arbitrage" we have decided from day zero and beyond go to to. And stability is increased by the simultaneous simulations, so what happens in one simulation is just of the many, and while we can increase these to thousands, we have not yet done so – for the simple reason that was requested to be conversative and not increase any resource side at this point. We are trying to approach it "conservatively" for now, but it is almost impossible to know in advane all the responses from the "AI Agents" outside of the "background agents." At least a priori. Anything you can suggest of course will be evaluated and taken hint at. We are here to do that. This is not a political answer. You can send your proposal say in DM if you prefer. We will consider all such proposals.

If you have a good signal, you can amplify that by the trading volume. If you believe you have such signals, this is clearly beneficial strategy. But note that there is a risk involved: if that signal turns out to be bad, there is also a penalty that is based on the distribution of those Sharpes (across the simulations). So, a couple of bad mistakes can lead to a penalty, but then again, very good performance with good volume across simulations will take you to 20 % top. To make this stable, in our view, is about having those simultaneous simulations going on, as we of course undertand mistakes happen in risk management and in trading, sometimes PnL goes down, MDD is >10 % and so on. But the point is to try to hit the right spots, and if observing a mistake across the simulations in the strategy, then advised to "manage that risk" either by the advanced order-types we have put in, or take precautions and not run with the herd – the typical stuff that may happen in such complex systems. Sometimes in the real markets somebody hits the jackpot, even by pure luck, but we try to avoid its influence "in continuous rewarding system" by having the simultaneous simulations. True, it might be this is too far taken, and we may take it to evalation over the whole trading day. Has been one of the plans. But, then, this is clearly not rewarding "in continuous time," as our target has been to go into "deep HFT" type of scenario, with continuos inventory control, and careful order placement in the book. And those aggressive orders, we allow them to be taken now even without transaction costs, so those that attempt to leverage on that risk they take, can do so without harmful transaction cost, but at the same time, they will gamble if they do not have a genuine signal behind that. And staying just behind everybody, with limit-orders, well, this is not something that, say, market-makes or active traders would pursue either. They want to actually build up the PnL consistently over the day. One of the things, I can say already, in the preparations, is to move to a bit different calculation method of the PnL. More about that later. It is a process we are doing here, and sometimes have to take some steps into the unknown. We are trying to keep the "continuous rewarding system" because it is in a way much more exciting to succeed in that, rather than wait for the horses to finish in 10,000 mile race.

@taos・79 ☯️ We have pushed and deployed a minor update in order to start addressing some issues in the incentive distribution; no action needed from miners or validators (will be deployed automatically at the start of the next simulation hour).  The update includes:

- **Sharpe Assessment Window Fullness Requirement** : Newly registered miners will not receive a score until enough observations to amount to 80% of the Sharpe assessment window (currently 1 simulation hour) are available.  This is to prevent unfair assignment of high scores to newly registered miners due to incomplete assessment data.
- **Moving Average Alpha Adjustment** : The parameter which determines the period of the EMA applied to miner scores is adjusted so as to amount to ~5 minutes of simulation time.  This is aimed at decreasing the variance of incentives and better rewarding consistency; this slight increase in the period is likely just the first step in this direction, with other modifications and further gradual adjustments to this parameter to be made over the coming weeks.  This is necessary also to attempt to reduce the vTrust gap between ourselves and other validators, which results largely from discrepancies in weight assignment due to highly varying miner performance together with rapid changes in incentive values.

Investigation, evaluation and testing ongoing for several other matters related to the simulation model which will be announced next week, and may be other minor adjustments with similar objectives to the above depending on monitoring outcomes.

Further upgrades are upcoming, as well, as mentioned, and they will be then also related to the LOB, and the "background agents," especially the high-frequency trading market-makers that work there. They will be given an upgrade, likely in the next week's release, and we are studying a way to give AI template to the AI miner community here to help in that process.

And yes, if the above (just made) updates will not be sufficient, we take another one. The target is to "optimize" like an algorithm would, and sometimes it makes for a bit bumpy ride – you cannot optimize without taking some risks in the process. @taos・79 ☯️ This week's update:

- **Incentive Adjustment** : Scoring parameters are further adjusted to decrease volatility of incentives and better reward consistent performance.  EMA for score calculation is increased to **20 minutes** and Sharpe assessment window is expanded to **2 hours** (both in simulation time).  To avoid zeroing all scores until new Sharpe window is filled, scores will still be assigned once 1 hour of data is available.
- **Book Count Increase** : Number of books will be increased from 32 to **40**.
- **Taker Fee Re-Introduced** : A **0.023%** fee will be applied on **taker** trades executed by miners.  This is aimed at discouraging careless aggression and motivating provision of liquidity within the simulated markets.
- **Background Model Stability** : Having observed some undesirable market conditions arising as a result of particular behaviour of miner agents, the background model parameters and logic have been refined so as to improve the stability of the simulated book state under extreme conditions.  This involves an increase in the reaction speed of HFT agents such that they are able to change their position more rapidly while also dynamically adjusting order sizes, especially during periods with particularly low liquidity, as well as improvements to the intelligence of Futures agents in terms of their application of the signal when calculating next actions.
- **Memory Allocation & Usage Optimization** : An upgraded allocator is applied to the system, allowing to further accelerate the computations involved in simulation management, alongside a couple of additional refinements to reduce the amount of memory accumulated over long simulation runs.
- **Data-Intensive Agent Preparations** : Tools and a preliminary example agent illustrating the use of the full resolution of available data provided through the L3 record attached to the state update are currently in testing; only some preparations for this are included in the update today while finalizing and verifying these elements, expect to publish the example agent and first tools later this week.  This represents a necessary step towards facilitating the deployment of miners utilizing data-driven strategies which demand access to the highest available granularity of data, of which AI-based strategies are a key example - framework and example for application of AI in agent logic is also in the works.

Further explanations for those wanting to read more about it:

Recall that you have 20x "cap" (wrt the intial capital given at the start of the simulation) on how much volume you can create before your orders will be stopped from entering the exchange. So, optimally, you would like to place your orders with highest possible volume in cases where you see the most benefit and possibility of reaching high Sharpe, and on the other hand, if you are very uncertain, use low volumes. But overall making sure you would use "maximal" amount of volume, because if you would not, you might not be taking advantage of the best opportunities and you would likely lose to others.

You can think of this as being controlled by a manager at a trading desk: you can take certain risks, but must remain within certain capital use limits. We do not currently enforce minimum amount of trading volume, like we did in the past, we rather now control the maximum, as per this risk management "exercise" or optimization scheme. Clearly keeping things in control while using the maximal available trading volumes, without going further, is a difficult optimization problem. This is where we believe AI methods are useful, it is not only about the signal extraction, but also how much you should weight it.

The current implementation does give a penalty if doing bad mistakes. But we have increased the calculation window further in this latest version to two hours (see above). This penalty is "asymmetric," that is, you can have a great overall performance of Sharpes, but then destroy that by having a few bad mistakes, This reflect the real-world risk taking in a way that a few bad mistakes can wipe you out from the business, in the extreme cases like Knight Capital did (https://www.sec.gov/files/litigation/admin/2013/34-70694.pdf). So we think such penalty must exist for making bad decisions.

> While processing 212 small retail orders that Knight had received from its customers,
> SMARS routed millions of orders into the market over a 45-minute period, and obtained over 4
> million executions in 154 stocks for more than 397 million shares. By the time that Knight
> stopped sending the orders, Knight had assumed a net long position in 80 stocks of approximately
> $3.5 billion and a net short position in 74 stocks of approximately $3.15 billion. Ultimately,
> Knight lost over $460 million from these unwanted positions.

Note that we are able to allow the AI Agents to short-positions and trading on margin, but we have not yet activated that, as it would further increase the risks (and rewards). This is going to be activated soon enough, most likely sometime in July, or early August.

1. How exactly is the 20× capital limit calculated?
Is it based on the total volume of all submitted orders, only executed volume, or something else?
Does repeated use of capital (e.g., buying and selling the same amount 100 times) count as 100× or 1×?


2. Does the volume limit reset periodically?
Is the 20× limit enforced over the entire simulation, or does it reset over time (e.g., every 2 hours like the Sharpe evaluation window)?


3. How is the penalty mechanism for bad trades implemented?
What qualifies as a "bad mistake"?
Is there a fixed threshold (e.g., Sharpe < -1), or is it based on rolling performance metrics such as Sharpe ratio or standard deviation over time?

1. The limit is on total traded volume in terms of QUOTE value, not sure what you mean "buying and selling the same amount", assets are fungible, any amount executed in a trade contributes to your total trading volume.
2. The limit is on total traded volume over the previous 24 hours of simulation time (rolling window); this is carried over between simulations i.e. if simulation is reset, or a new simulation starts, the volumes used to determine if you have exceeded the cap are carried over.
3. A penalty is applied on outliers, so if you have mostly Sharpe values in a range of say 0.5-0.7 on each book, and then on one book you have -1.0, this will incur a penalty.

Would encourage you to study [the code](https://github.com/taos-im/sn-79/blob/f7cacecf15552f8f052c3d9fff9aea14ab0d9c60/taos/im/validator/reward.py#L175) if you wish to fully understand the mechanism.

I made changes to the agent code. Improvement, I think. If the improvement works, then the incentive should become larger. You wrote that the EMA is now 2 hours. Do I understand correctly that in 2 epoches I can see an increase in incentive, if the improvement works? or later?

Ah, ok -  the Sharpe window is 2 simulation hours, but this is a rolling window so new performance observations from the updated miner will enter the window immediately, although the overall performance will include observations from prior to the update as well until 2 simulation hours have passed.  Also should note that the EMA for the miner score (from which weights are obtained) is 20 simulation minutes, so that there is a smoothing effect on the change in incentive relative to rewards, meaning that it will take a bit of time for increases in miner performance over the Sharpe window to reflect in the incentive.  Quite difficult to say exactly how long you might need to wait to see clearly the effect on performance of the new agent, but after 2 simulation hours the Sharpe assessment will be entirely on the new agent.

Why would we disappear?

To be clear, we have released basically every week (significant) improvements, sometimes two per week. We have increased from 10 simultaneous simulations to 40, and can do much more, if we just want to (hundreds, or even thousands). The actual limit-order book "modeling" challenge is just about getting started as the technical setup is ready for that, and the few issues we have had have been resolved, or we know how to resolve them. Since the incentive mechanism change, we observe much more dispersion between the miners, which is something we consider much more interesting (and hopefully, also the miners would do) than the earlier one that had very "stable" but rather unrealistic scenario compared to real-world algorithms that actually take risk and have to resolve risk management. Whether we are now at an "ideal" setup in terms of the incentives, wouldn not yet say so, but we observe a disteibution of incentives that reward the top 20 % more than the rest (80 %), and more competitive environment as a consequence – and this, gives a much better chance of real-world applications.

Secondly, we have laid out at least 6 to 12 months plan already before, and that includes especially "HFT" capable simulation system with special focus on AI. This is what we call deep HFT. Technically, we can reach this even sooner, but since we know we will also want to do other improvements along the way, it is rather safe to say we are in the track of long-term commitment. Personally, having been in this kind of field for 20+ years, and don't think I can ever change that to something else. Also, we have background in HFT market making, which makes it even more seriuosly involved business proposal, as we know we are interested in taking this to its logical theoretical limit in speed and in intelligence building. This includes major innovations in the science side as well, mainly meaning how to model the limit-order book dynamically in real-time conditions, with the help from AI and decentralized computing. We are just getting started, like Bittensor is getting started in real applications.

@taos・79 Hello guys, we do not expect any significant departures to appear on this week's Wednesday release. Fine-tuning things. Importantly, at the technical side, we are working on significant speed and memory adjustments that would help the project to grow faster, these updates may or may not come out on Wednesday's release, depending how the testing will go today and tomorrow. Testing priority. Not going to drop this prematurely. May have some computer spec increase linked.

Secondly, we have been working on to allow short-selling and margin-buying to be done by the AI Agents. This is technically ready with small adjustments here and there, but since we also have to educate how to use that, and adapt to it correctly, it is not going to be yet released this week. You can however already "adjust" somewhat by reading how such are implemented at exchange level. Could be next week, or later in July. To help to leverage your good positions to gain more edge over bad ones.

Thirdly, we are working on improving the dashboard, as mentioned before. Unlikely to be ready yet this week, however. It is going to be more intuitive and better looking, but as always, we do it as a process, so after that release they may still be things to change. This is scheduled to be released in July, essentially providing better UI to access the subnet and understand it. We would like to have the dashboard be focused more on how AI Agents are viewing things, rather than being a technical board.

Fourth, AI template(s) are being worked on, but let us see if we can yet provide one this week. Why AI could matter here? We understand that manually fine-tuning your algorithms can be time costly to do, and from market dynamics perspectives it is also going to be quite necessary later on (at least). We are deciding on the type AI algorithms to be released. One of the reasons we started this project was to see how far we can take AI in terms of speed and reaction time in the decentralized side.

I will let a bit more technical details to be explained by @6/. I am mostly working on some UI and blog-post/articles side myself, we expect July to go into more "user experience" side matters than before, and less of technical improvements that have been doing to this a lot. Time to start spending more time on documentation, templates, articles, and all that experience side!

More details will be provided in later announcement, but just to follow up and confirm the basic intentions for this week's release:
- Some improvements to the query process are being tested and likely to be included, this aimed at reducing the time spent in processing messages during the state publish in order to improve the overall simulation progression rate and prepare for further increases in book count.  Likely we will increase our validator resources this week, primarily just to provide a larger buffer against resource-related instability.
- Margin trading indeed has been technically ready in simulator for a while, some refinements underway to ensure readiness for use by our miners, but testing to ensure robustness, as well as updates to monitoring and documentation to ensure this can be confidently and safely utilized, will require more time.
- Revamped dashboard is in the works, existing dashboard will be checked and updated to improve readability and usefulness in light of some of the recent changes to incentive mechanism.
- First step towards AI-based strategy template will be the inclusion of tools enabling intuitive and efficient management of state history data; this week's release will include such a tool allowing to reconstruct L2 states for every event and manage retention of this data over a configurable time window so that this can be used in the production of signals requiring a higher granularity of data.

@taos・79 ☯️ This week's update is fairly light, but includes a couple of important refinements and additions:

- **Query Process Optimization** : Computationally time-intensive processes involved in handling preparation of miner queries have been optimized to reduce the time spent in this aspect of the simulation management; this is aimed at increasing the rate of simulation time progression relative to real-world time and prepares for further increases in book count.  Book count is not being increased this week as we focus on first improving stability and efficiency.  **Miners, note that you will need to update at latest when deployed to validators as this includes changes to the message compression handling**
- **Data Management Tools** : Tools providing a simple mechanism by which miners are able to process state updates in order to construct a detailed history of the book state at each event occurrence (order placement, cancellation or trade) are included, along with a new example agent implementation which utilizes this in a straightforward way, are included in this update.  This represents the first step towards supporting the development of data-intensive trading strategies, of which AI-based methods are of course an important sub-class.  Note that the example strategy is not currently intended to work easily straight out of the box on minimal hardware due to the volume of data and complexity of the state reconstruction process; rather this illustrates the usage of the history management class and provides guidance as to how this might be applied.  Explicitly, with the current timeout setting, completing the history reconstruction for the latest state within the timeout is not expected to be feasible without some serious hardware.  More efficient implementations are being explored and will be included if successfully tested, but we expect miners who wish to make use of the higher-frequency, "deep" data to build on top of the basic tools to construct a system that enables to achieve their specific goals.  We of course welcome any queries, feedback, requests and suggestions that would enable us to assist in this endeavour!
- **Reward Distribution Adjustment** : No changes to the incentive mechanism this week, but a small adjustment to the distribution of rewards.  This change reduces the difference in incentive between the top and average miners, and is necessary currently to try and improve validator weights agreement while we still do not observe any miners remaining consistently among the top 20%.

We will also upgrade our validator instance to provide more of a buffer against spikes in memory consumption, as well as to better leverage the latest optimizations.

As mentioned in an earlier message https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1353733356470276096/1391812518657261568, several substantial updates are in the works and planned for release over the next couple of weeks, including margin trading capability, revamped dashboard and full AI-based strategy template and example.  Also remains to apply some adjustments to the current dashboard in order to better reflect the relevant data in agent assessment, this will most likely only be completed later in the week.

**The listed updates will be pushed at ~15:00 UTC today.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~2H following the push.

anyone else getting ddose’d on this subnet?

In short, agents need to maximize average risk adjusted performance (Sharpe ratio being the relevant metric) over all books, with preference given to agents who do so while actively trading (i.e. with higher traded volume).

So there should not be failed trades and the bigger the trade amount, the bigger alpha token I could take.
Right?

"Failed" trades? You mean producing negative profit (loss)? Yes, you want to avoid that. You want to maximize the correct hits, and do that with "max volume," but you need to be aware that 20x the intial capital given is the max you are allowed to do, otherwise you are being blocked from putting new orders/trade again. This is important. Another important thing is that if you get negative profits (loss), then those are penalized more strongly; that is, if you get a good average positive Sharpe, but have big negative ones as well, they will penalize the average. So, this penalty, and the max allowed trade (20x) you have to take into account. Those have been discussed here on this channel quite a bit before, you can scroll to see those discussions.

@taos・79 ☯️ Will be pushing and deploying a minor update a bit later today; back-compatibility was tested so should not require immediate update by miners or validators, but recommended as always to deploy the latest version ASAP:

- **Response Timeout Increase** : Since continuing to see low average successful response rate from miners, the response timeout will be increase from 2.0 to **3.0 seconds** to provide more time for miners to download, decompress and process state updates.
- **Further Query Process Optimization** : Additional investigation and testing revealed a more performant method for state deserialization by validator, which should further reduce the time taken in handling the miner query process.
- **Miner Response Compression** : A bug in the routine handling compression of miner responses before return to validator was patched; this involves some changes to the message handling, but have designed and tested for back-compatibility so should not affect ability to communicate with validators running either the latest or previous version of the code.
- **General Maintenance** : A few minor additional updates also applied, including a change in the miner logging to more clearly indicate their role in trades, more complete documentation for the `response` methods (`limit_order`, `market_order`, `cancel_order`), and a fix to restore function of the agent testing proxy.

The code will be pushed and deployed to our validator at **~15:00 UTC** today.

@taos・79 ☯️ No significant technical updates this week, focus has been on stability and documentation while previously mentioned projects are still in progress:

- **Finalized Optimizations** : Following the latest optimizations to the query process deployed last week, a lot of time has gone into monitoring the effects and debugging some issues; this was already solved over the course of a few pushes throughout the week.  We still target to further improve the speed of handling state updates and miner querying, but have now applied all those improvements which are possible without major overhaul, and observe stable operation of the validator over extended periods.  This prepares us for further increases to book count and clarifies the path to take in further upgrading the system to address aspects which still run slower than we would like.
- **Agent Documentation** : The first iteration of a document aimed at summarising the key tools and understanding necessary for the development of miner agent strategies will be put to the repo.  We hope that current and potential miners will find this useful in clarifying certain matters, and welcome any feedback, queries or suggestions to improve and expand on the content.  Commentary has also been added and updated in the code itself to facilitate comprehension of the role and attributes of classes involved in the protocol definitions.
- **Dashboard Update** : Minor adjustments to the metrics and dashboard have been made in order to better provide for monitoring under the latest incentive mechanism; more thorough overhaul of the dashboard is in the works, and content-wise the most important next steps will revolve around the inclusion of data relevant to margin trading enablement.

The process to finalize and enable miner utilization of margin trading capability in the simulator is ongoing, and we of course continually monitor behaviour and incentives to assess for opportunities to refine the overall simulation outcomes.  Additional steps have been taken towards providing AI-capable agent templates, but further development is required to collect this into a release-ready package.

**Updates will be pushed at ~15:00 UTC today.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~2h following as usual.

To expand technically a little (though the above message already covers most of the critical information):

- Margin trading capability has been available in simulator, being employed by at least one of the background agent types in certain scenarios; we aim now to make this functionality available to miners.  Most of the pieces are in place, remains currently to ensure that convenient access is provided to all the data and functions necessary to manage leveraged positions, to expand the dashboard metrics to include monitoring data relevant to margin orders, then to finalize testing and documentation to ensure that this can be smoothly adopted.
- AI trading templates will be based around a framework targeting to simplify the process of applying models for inference on the τaos data format , with a focus on identifying and exemplifying an approach which follows some established literature while being tractable for execution in the limited time available for state processing.  Once we are able to demonstrate the applicability of AI approaches in decision making, the next stage will involve the development of a pipeline to facilitate continuous training of models on the published state data (for which the previously released high-frequency state reconstruction and history management tools are expected to be put into more meaningful action).

These two updates together will create the basis on which we hope deeply intelligent and adaptive strategies with complex risk management will be built and deployed, so we can leverage the full power and expertise of the Bittensor network and community ☯️

Hi guys,

I’m a miner and I’m worried about the trend of burning miners’ emission. I don’t want to spend time or resources on networks where a significant portion of the emission is burned.

Could you be frank about how you view new miners—do you actually need us, or do you think we’ll just take a share of your emission?

What’s your stance on subnetworks burning miners’ emission? Are you burning any emission now, or planning to in the future?

Thanks for the honesty.

We are always happy to welcome new miners, diversity of strategies is a desirable feature within our design and miners contributions are a vital and valuable component of the system.

We do not currently burn any emissions, and do not have any plans to do so.  I do believe there are certain scenarios in which burning may make sense for subnets with a particular model, but this is not something we foresee to be necessary in our case, and would certainly not implement unilaterally without open discussion and careful consideration of the impact on all participants.

I hope this addresses your concerns.

Yeah so first of all, we have templates in design that precisely plan to attract more miners. These miners would come from several backgrounds, but especially those that have some, or a lot, of financial trading experience, or even HFT background. Definitely people interested in AI application with real financial context. We have not even started this "marketing" since we need those AI templates first, we have taken steps to describe more precisely how to build such algorithms. So I would say we take this side very seriously. We are not interested in homogenous setting. The whole setup was made for a heterogenous setting – indeed if one would just use the same algorithm logic and scale that, it would likely fail in our future settings since it will have market impact that will eat into the homogenously acting miners. So, from side as well, heterogenuity and many different miners is intended to be the status quo. We cannot of course stop actors that would perform extremely well with scaled up processes, but as mentioned, it would get increasingly more difficult with more market impact.

Attached here some more visualizations related to our oversight of the subnet; data is collected every 15 minutes over the previous week (16-23 Jul) for the 5 keys with the highest observed incentive values over the period.  These figures present an overview of the incentive profile, a histogram indicating the frequency of observations at different incentive levels, and the cumulative distribution function for the data with the median value highlighted.  

These analyses assist us in understanding the longer term performance of miners in order to identify those exhibiting desirable behaviour, as well as to alert us if there are anomalies which may correspond to some form of manipulation or technical issue, providing insight on how we might best prioritise development for the health of the subnet.

Note to all here. This selection of five keys is based on the maximum performance over the time period. This is not totally satisfactory as can be seen with those keys that most of their incentives at lower levels. Better definition of super performance would be based on more consistent behavior and this will be applied soon I am confident of that.

The point is to showcase that some miners have found some consistency in their performance, using the trading volume weighting to their favour to get into the top 30 % that are more incentivized. So, the goal of the miners is still the same, to learn how to use trading volume to weight their best performance, and avoid weighting bad performances.

Naturally, as can be seen also, there is a lot of variability here, but it is certainly more interesting and realistic that avoiding risk and trading with minimal volumes. We will be posting this kind of analyses here weekly to help out especially the more new-comers to undertand what is going on. Also more seasoned guys should find these somewhat useful.

If you are interested in these tools mining, as per subnet, let us know here. Our goal is to help access to the most interesting subnets and of course make subnet 79 in particular more accessible. We do understand modeling in financial markets is difficult and one needs several tools and patience to fine-tune the models, with or without AI.

@taos・79 ☯️ This week we release the margin trading capability to miners, alongside some further optimizations and refinements:

- **Margin Trading** : With this update, we enable the use of leverage by miners in placing orders to the simulator.  This allows to implement new classes of strategies which make use of loan facilities offered by the exchange to optimize trading logic and risk management.
- **State Publishing Optimization** : The process for construction and publishing of state messages from the simulator side has been reviewed and refined to exclude extraneous data and provide more configurability to prepare for handling of increased order books.  This should result in some improvement in overall progression rate, while we also work on much more significant improvements to this mechanism so as to eliminate delays resulting from this procedure more conclusively.

AI/ML agent example strategy and template production is also progressing, with some preliminary structure and logic already being prepared; this will be released once we are satisfied with the level of generality and the simplicity of customization in order that we can attempt to encourage miners to deploy more diverse and adaptive agents, and thus create even more interesting simulated data. 

**Updates will be pushed at ~15:00 UTC today.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed 2H following the push.
**This release includes a number of changes to the simulator, as well additions and revisions at protocol level, which will require validators to restart simulations and for miners to update their software in order to maintain communication.**

Apologies for the somewhat short notice, a few last minute issues together with a couple OOO team members has created some delays.  We are back to full strength today; additionally should note upcoming company meeting, during which focus will shift somewhat towards high level planning and discussions, although we expect in any case to resume production of more comprehensive releases including simulation parameter changes, deeper optimizations and expanded strategy samples and templates.

@taos・79 ☯️ The updates described earlier https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1353733356470276096/1400125010739331254 have been pushed, and will be deployed at our vali in ~2 hours.  :partyfast:

**Miners**
Please prepare to update your miners to the latest version when the update is deployed to validator in about 2 hours.
You can check out the usage of margin capability by observing the changes in the [`response` class](https://github.com/taos-im/sn-79/blob/main/taos/im/protocol/response.py), or have a look at the simple demonstration implemented in the latest [`RandomMaker`](https://github.com/taos-im/sn-79/blob/main/agents/RandomMakerAgent.py) and [`RandomTaker`](https://github.com/taos-im/sn-79/blob/main/agents/RandomTakerAgent.py) example agents.  The [order testing agent](https://github.com/taos-im/sn-79/blob/main/agents/OrderOptionAgent.py) also contains some straightforward tests which may be helpful in understanding the accounting for leveraged orders.

Note as always that the latest update is now also running on our testnet (netuid 366).
Dashboard is available at [testnet.simulate.trading](https://testnet.simulate.trading/).

Note to all. We will be keeping eye on any problems caused by the short-selling / margin-buying feature. This feature has been rather long in the making, and was one of the original "problem points," causing significant delays in production. The accounting side of that is a bit difficult to test and maneuver, so it is fair to say we have to see how it behaves.

But then again, if you are not taking leveraged position, this should not really affect you. The leveraged positions were made available in preparation for more market-making type of actions and efficient inventory controlling. In market making, one typically likes to stay around zero inventory, on either side, long or short, and avoid big risk taking.

Since this has been one of the main agendas we have had with this project, we have put quite a bit of emphasis on this feature. In knowing hands, it can be very handy and powerful, while in more inexperienced hands it can cause havoc. Like in modern exchanges it often is. So you are advised to be careful with it, use testnet, and learn by doing.

The long-term being the "deep HFT" capability, we wish this feature set will lay out more degrees of freedom for the algorithm developers. Now you can then use even more trading volume to gain edge, at the right time. Once the AI Template(s) are available, one can take advantage of this more significantly – that is our expectation anyhow.

In modern market settings, the ability to short-sell and use leverage is wide-spread. Although we are taking somewhat of a gamble here in preparation of the future features, we think it is worth a shot and those seriously interested in building real-world applications and algorithms to real markets and exchanges, should be thrilled!

We will share more information soon, and also provide the "usual" performance diagrams / histograms / CDFs to you.

Here's some of the latest (7 days) performance figures we promised to deliver. The first is about the "max performers" over the last seven (7) days. The next set is about the consistent best and worst performers, plus an average performing key. The latter therefore shows the differences between the best and the worst.
The dispersion "group."

The goal of showing such figures is not only to help and educate the miners on these, but also for us to observe how things progress, what keys are performing the best, how much difference the best and the worst have, and how many UIDs different keys hold. This is done to help us to make the Sn better. Also note that the system allows to observe other Sn performance, so it can be adapted easily to theirs.
Should you find such interesting, let us know to give you some access.

Also as we know there has been discussion on whether dTAO has been good or not. I can say no matter what, we keep developing, and have no intent to stop under no circumstances. So, whether these talks matter for us, it is simple: does not. Of course, we want the whole ecosystem to flourish and therefore it is important to help each other, and the talk about Sns being "competitors" (only) to each, I think it is not a wise call. The whole ecosystem is better the more there are quality and therefore it is very short-term to think of only certain Sns. We keep developing and hope and trust the system will pick off, and I think the system will become more resilient over time.

@taos・79 ☯️ We plan to release as usual several updates later today; announcing earlier as this includes quite significant changes to certain parameters, which may require some miners to revise their strategies:

* **Miner Instruction Distribution** : In order to address issues in simulation realism arising due to highly clustered processing of instructions from miners, we have made some modifications to the logic which relates to this aspect.  The first and most significant is a **reduction of the publishing interval from 5 simulation seconds to 1 simulation second** - this means that miners will receive a new state update every 1 second of simulation time.  The other important component is a change in the mapping of response times to simulation latency; the maximum delay applied will be 1s (if responding just within the timeout), with a distribution applied which results in response times between 0-2s producing latency in range 10-200ms (sim time), while responses received in the last second of the timeout will have latencies betweeen 200 and 1000ms applied.  We will also restrict the maximum count of instructions allowed to be submitted in a single response to contain at most 5 instructions per book (down from 20). **Miners, if you expect that these changes will require significant changes to your deployed strategies that cannot be completed before release today, please state your case here or privately so that we can consider if it will be necessary to postpone this change to a release later in the week**.  The interval reduction will result also in quite substantially slower simulation time progression, we are working on ways to further optimize the query process to reduce the impact, but is anyway a necessary sacrifice to improve the quality of the data produced by the subnet which also moves us a little closer towards the goal of full HFT trading capability.
* **Simulator Parameter Updates** : Simulator parameters simultaneously receive some adjustments to improve the behaviour of the background market, particularly in terms of price stability.  This is aimed at enabling the production of more significant "bubbles" and "bursts" within the simulated market, for which we may also include some local agent logic changes already creating such "shock events" coordinated across all simulated books.  This is an important step towards providing for more meaningful analyses of "flash crashes" and similar events, which are quite central to the utility of the subnet as a powerful risk management analysis tool.  We will confirm if this is included in the release upon pushing of code.
* **Diagnosis Tools & Bugfixes** : Some pernicious issues in accounting for margin trading activity arising under very specific conditions have been under deep investigation, resulting in development of new testing tools and extensions to logging mechanisms which enable more convenient diagnosis in general, alongside the fixes themselves.
* **Example Agent Refinements** : Several updates to the basic example agents to produce more varied activity as well as a number of optimizations to the AI-based agent introduced last week are included in the release.  We have also updated the `run_miner` script to select the AI agent by default in order to encourage the exploration of these techniques and push for more intelligent and diverse behaviour by all in the subnet.

**Code will be pushed to the repository at ~14:00 UTC.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~2H following the push.

**MINERS : Again, please pay special attention to the first item above and let us know if you would find it necessary to request a delay in the release of this change.**

@taos・79 ☯️ **Miners**
You may have noticed that the latest simulation exhibits unusual flat price evolution; after examination this is revealed to be due to miners simply placing large quantities of limit orders at or near the best levels, resulting in an insurmountable "volume wall" which background agents are not able to remove, at least with the current configuration.  This most likely arises due to the reduction in publishing interval, which results in those that simply place orders every round now doing so more often.

We would like to appeal to those miners that seek to find optimized performance in the subnet to recognize this as an opportunity by which to profit from the thoughtless behaviour of other participants - there are several liquidity-taking strategy implementations which would allow to extract profits from the lazy, while also restoring reasonable properties to the market and enabling intelligent algorithms to continue to test and succeed in a dynamic environment.

We are working on providing an example agent to facilitate the elimination of this scenario, and expect also that upcoming further upgrades to the background market will prevent this situation from persisting in future simulations.  We of course develop also modifications specifically to address this issue, but will require careful testing so as not to disturb other sensitive aspects of the simulated markets.
