@taos・79 Hello guys! Today on Wednesday, we will be releasing a few things at around the usual time 5pm UTC:

- Another bug fix to shortselling / margin-buying accounting side that occur in some corner cases we have analyzed and has created some crashes of the simulation, more details of this will be given by @6/. later today.

- To help to debug in such accounting matters, we have also developed a replayer that we will be using in the future.

- We are working and testing to put more intelligence to a special group of background agents mimicing Hedge Fund behavior. This trader type that has already existed, but used pretty simple type of approach previously, and has been an integral part of (my past) quantitative research on things like bubbles, bursts, crashes. And now we have moved into the direction to push that in. For those agents, volatility is one of the key ingredients, among other basic statistical estimates. 

Incorporating more of this intelligence will lead to wilder performance, the intent is to find the best performing parameter estimates. However, as usual, the AI Agents have a significance say in this, so the end result will also depend on things out of our reach, and we will be fine-tuning things accordingly. The testing we are currently doing and likely deploying today, in some format or another, is to create more dynamic behavior that will also affect the LOB dynamics in a realistic fashion.

I would give more story and motivation behind this new "stylized intelligence" once the new features are released, since the testing is still ongoing in the background and rather would not promise 100 % that it will be released in the desired format now. There is some update in that direction, and more will be coming in any case in the next days and weeks to the extent that more serious AI model approaches would start to gain more ground and we are reaching our goals to simulate and model risks adequately, first to the level of academic precision (meaning, "stylized") and then going into more fine-tuning mode with particular assets in mind. There would be a lot to say here, but rather would not get into that right now since we have taken a deep dive into matters and naturally everything being C++ we are a bit slowed down with that complexity. So, hopefully you guys understand this is a long-term project with equally long-term benefits to it and big goals to reach for.

The above will help us all to better manage risks at high-frequency levels such as in flash crashes, and their mechanisms.

Also, as usual, I will be putting some performance metrics here to show you. Note that once we deploy the "more intelligence" we expect more bumpy ride and therefore miners at that point want to check on matters cautiously.

@taos・79 ☯️ This week's update already largely described above, and a few of the changes previously planned for inclusion today were deployed in earlier updates, but here a summary and some additional details:

* **Accounting Bugfix** : Another very rare edge case encountered in live simulations which doesn't appear in tests is corrected for; of course we prefer that no such incidents occur, but to put in a positive light, this indicates that miners are deploying real and unique strategies which implement logic outside of the "typical".  We have been working on developing tests and tools to improve detection and expedite diagnosis of such scenarios.
* **Simulator Parameter Updates** : Simulator parameters receive some adjustments to improve the behaviour of the background market, this being largely in response to the quite flat price evolution observed in the latest simulations and includes several modifications which are expected to create more "bubbles and bursts".  Occurrence of these type of events in the simulation is vital to the objective of providing data enabling to properly assess and manage risk in the real world.  Again, the live market situation demonstrates clearly that the inclusion of distributed, human-controlled agents in the simulation creates meaningful changes in the orderbook evolution as compared to purely theoretical and controlled experiments; fine-tuning the background market in reaction to newly observed behaviours is an important and expected part of the subnet management, and each update brings us closer to fully realistic market dynamics.
* **Replay Tool** : Although not yet ready to be included to the public codebase, it should be noted that we are creating tools which enable to "replay" the exact evolution of simulations having occurred in live so as to facilitate reproduction and diagnosis of errors, more deeply examine miner behaviour and test new updates against a market which accurately reflects the latest dynamics with real miners involved.  This is one of several projects aimed at improving our ability to predict and resolve issues arising due to the behaviour of miner agents.

**Code will be pushed to the repository at ~17:00 UTC.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~1H following the push.

@taos・79 Hello guys, as usual, today we release updates to the framework. More information coming up soon. Just some notes now: We have been working on (still) some remaining bugs that plague the short-selling / margin-buying side, and are mitigating accounting matters (hopefully the last bits!) today by introducing smallest order-volumes, others being rejected.

We are also increasing some of the "inherent" volatility (uncertainty of price path direction and scale) giving better chances to momentum based trading at certain times, and a wider range of options of trading algorithms. Bunch of other technical things in the works that can help the system to become more resilient and lean in terms of data. More about that after the release. The direction we want to take this into is larger application space, including but not limited to option pricing.

@taos・79 ☯️ This week's update includes a few additions, revisions and optimizations, with several other projects currently in the works:

* **Momentum Example Agent** : A new example strategy will be included which uses Hurst exponent estimation to generate trading signals; this is the first in a series of new templates aimed at exemplifying the use of different classes of strategies, which we hope will encourage and assist miners to incorporate new techniques into their operations.
* **Simulator Parameter Updates** : Further adjustments to the simulator background to increase volatility and create more dynamic and realistic environment are applied.
* **Reporting Revisions** : The reporting process executed by validator to enable monitoring via dashboard has been optimized somewhat to reduce the time taken in this activity, and the handling revised to avoid blocking the query process where the reporting is not completed before the next query round starts.  This does mean that there will be a reduction in the frequency at which the metrics are reported, but also an improvement in the rate of progression of the simulation.
* **Bugfixes** : Unfortunately encountering some new issues in accounting handling arising in edge cases following the previous updates, these have been investigated and solutions are produced and in testing.  **Note that this includes an update which allows to set a minimum order size that will be accepted by the exchange - the value will be fixed to 0.01 BASE in the release.**  The complexity and sensitivity of the simulator accounting is of course necessary to ensure accurate and fair evaluation, but does lead to a lot of these types of concerns when introducing intelligent human agents which execute a wide variety of techniques.  The more of these types of scenarios we encounter and fix, the closer we get to full stability of the simulator under _any_ conditions, a key goal which we are now very close to achieving.
* **Logging Improvements** : Logging process for simulation events is being reviewed, refined and expanded to facilitate analysis and investigation, as well to reduce the size of the generated files.  The first of several planned steps towards this goal (minifying L3 log entries) is expected to be included in today's release.
* **Replay Tool** : The tool enabling to replay past simulations is still undergoing final refinements and testing, but will be put into use and included to codebase soon.

**Code will be pushed to the repository at ~17:00 UTC.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~1H following the push.

**Miners**
Note the new restriction on minimum order size (orders with less than 0.01 BASE quantity will be rejected), you may need to adjust strategy logic to account for this.

What do you mean by this? Again, we can only discuss matters related to miners, and our project, from technical and conceptual perspective. We have been updating now very important matters related to the "background agents," they have got more intelligence and we are closing in to more realistic time series behavioral patterns. The different actors are next going to be calibrated to their respective realistic range of capital. We are also every week including new stuff. What we have had difficulty with was the short-selling and margin-buying features, since there were many (many!) accounting issues in different corners that have taken a few weeks of our time. Now that we then finally hopefully cleared of that, we are back to focus more on the fine-tuning of the limit-order-book, and the real financial applications.

We have been aware of this for some time, and the matter is not to over-react, but conservatively approach and solve. Otherwise, there could be a lot of (and I mean, too much!) volatility that would not be good either. So, every day we keep eye on this and there are several upgrades coming that we have been researching and testing. More will be deployed. The background agents will get more intelligence or adaptation to situations that otherwise are problematic.
On Monday, we can give a status report on matters more closely and give our thoughts for the released in the next few weeks. With also the motivation "why" or "why not."

Notice that we cannot control what the miners do. Similarly, to the whole BT protocol, which has gone through many iterations that have solved corner cases after another, we are also doing that in a sense. Essentially, since we do not control those AI agents, there are cases we cannot fully prepare for and have to act when they happen. This means it is always some sort of exploration, but it makes the project stronger, not weaker.

I can put up a here the main concept what we want to take further. It is one of a few that are totally doable, and as we are into this for long-term, as long as it takes, as long as BIttensor exists (and longer, we move somewhere else in that case). The main reason we do several simulation is because we want to explore risk management and especially the so-called "black swans" or unusual crashes, bubbles, and associated phenomena that are very costly to investors, traders, and even hedge funds that typically are the best informed of market developments. By repeated trials, and realistic trials in that, we can simiarly to option pricing find out the "price of risk" and take that into account in any trading algorithm development. Furthermore, since we not only repeat several times, but also will be taking in "macro-news" and associated real-world events, like already as an example there is the futures market impact (in simple form, yet), we can calibrate the whole system to reflect some of the most typical assets traded in crypto. Also, we are mostly concerned with a bit less liquid names for the reason of asymmetric information in them, compared to BTC, say, which reflects the opinions and investment strategies of many more than, say, of TAO. The fact that we can do this simulation like we do here with ABM (agent-based models) means that we can also explain "why" certain things happen; why for example crashes happen, and how they could be forecasted better. And once the LOB has been better modeled, it will also include valuable information to allow for better strategies to be tested and taken then into live markets. These questions are so central to finance that the whole field of Monte Carlo -simulations, option pricing by numerical methods, and the most serious backtesters that take into account market impacts, or execution algorithms that necessarily have to do so, have always been wanting to seek out answers to the question mentioned above. But instead of relying on just AI to solve this, we want to also explain and undertand "why." This is also the reason why is takes more time to develop this system since we do not want to just "fix" things quickly, we also want to keep in grasp of the "what is going on" -aspect. Therefore, we do not want the machines to control us, it is the other way around this subnet is intended to work. And we do not only seek to resolve research questions. The value can be directly found in some of the said concepts, including precise "black swan" estimates, better forecasting methods at least when it comes down to volatility and risk management, plus liquidity available. What we cannot guarantee in practice is "would the algorithms make money in real markets." That will hinge on some of the more advanced features we are developing, and also for that reason we resort to C++ in order really crack that on chain.

I don't think it is general accepted topic by the moderators of these channels, we are dealing with content here, like all in Bittensor is concerned about content production. I have to remind of this because these channels are moderated. That said, Bittensor as protocol is similar to Bitcoin in a way, there is no "controlling body," and we keep developing what we have and building value internally as much as we can, and we know how to build up a great product. For other factors in the world that may matter, well, those are topics outside of this realm here. One could say similar of many quality projects, and claim there is not enough "content" or things are "progressing slowly" (or slower than expected), but that is oftent he case in software production that certain matters in complicated projects take a bit more time than initially envisioned. At the same time, we are learning and seeing new opportunities ahead, with universities and alike, and those do not just suddenly emerge over night, like they would not any startup or new projects taken into live mode in this fashion. Linux was not an overnight success in adoption, neither has been many other open-source projects. What we build up is long term things, and certainly we want things to work as soon as possible. We are increasing our head count in the development side, and also hiring marketing and business development people, but just randomly developing "value" is not possible, it is a long process that applies to all projects, especially if they really try to work on something more unique than the average.

@taos・79 ☯️ This week we only deploy a few further adjustments to the simulator parameters; there is though much in the works and going on behind the scenes:

* **Simulator Model Adjustments** : Today we deploy further modifications to the simulator parameters and background agent logic which allow the market to better adjust to different volatility conditions, and intend to create more long term price momentum together with an increased frequency and magnitude of sudden endogenous crashes and spikes.  These adjustments are informed by analysis of the latest live simulation data as well as varied testing under different simulated conditions, and are motivated also as always by comparisons with real markets.  Updates of this type should be expected almost every week as we constantly study the data and tune towards more realistic and interesting market evolution.
* **Replay Tool** : The tool enabling to replay past simulations has started to see some use in our diagnosis and testing, but still some minor technical issues to iron out before this is fully completed - we expect to include in next week's release.
* **Simulator<->Validator Communication Optimization** : Proof-of-concept for a much more efficient mechanism handling the sharing of state updates and responses locally between simulator and validator has been produced, with the revision of serialization methods throughout the simulator underway to enable this to be applied.  The simulator has seen a number of highly impactful optimizations which allow it to process a large number of books in parallel (as we will showcase soon), but the process involved in dealing with miner queries prevents to fully leverage these advancements - this change represents another step in the project to optimize the state publishing process in order to address the bottleneck which prevents more rapid simulation progression.  We expect to practically eliminate time spent in sharing the state information, preparing us also to handle much larger state messages in future.  This update is planned for release in 2 weeks.
* **Simulation Checkpointing** : The ability to resume stopped or failed simulations has been one of the features intended to be included in the simulator for some time already. A version of this was actually already implemented earlier in the development, but due to the scope and extent of other feature updates it was decided to be deferred until reaching a more stable state.  We have now reached the stage where this makes sense, and also designed a better mechanism which can be produced as a sort of "extension" of the state publishing refinement in the previous point.  The ability to resume simulations will allow us to deploy simulator updates without requiring to restart the running simulation, enabling more accurate and stable rewarding, better recovery from failures and a smoother deployment procedure.  We hope to complete this feature in the next 3-4 weeks.
* **Reporting & Analysis** : We have also been consistently internally expanding and refining the tools used in the monitoring and analysis of the subnet data to better support the tuning of market parameters, study of AI agent behaviour and detection and diagnosis of issues.
* **Dashboard Upgrade** : A completely custom rework of the monitoring dashboard has been in production for some time, with the aim of providing a smoother, more intuitive and interactive experience for those interested in observing our simulated markets and the activities of the agents participating therein.

**Code will be pushed to the repository at ~16:00 UTC.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~1H following the push.

I would like to add perhaps here a bit of larger context on the simulator model adjustments. We are working on a greater feature that is not so much related to the fine-tuning of parameters. The feature under work – which we have been investigating for at least two months already – is related to a new way of bringing about bubbles and crashes formation. Or maybe more accurarately put, a way to merge two types of modeling techniques into one.

This would create a system that has not been reported even in academic literature as such. If we are succesful in this, which we shall see first evidences of in the next 2-3 weeks ETA, then we will be seeking academic collaboration at a deeper level. The reason why this is interesting is that we can begin to understand why certain crashes and bubbles form. This is of greater interest in finance due to the need of better risk management.

Effectively, in trading, you are also interested in making more money. Obviously. This feature stack would allow better forecasts based on limit order book data alone. It could be combined with basically any intraday trading strategy.

Let me expand on this a bit to those not familiar why "fractional Brownian motion" (with mixture) might matter. First of all, this class of stochastic processes is alrady rather old and much studied, for about 50 years or so. That itself surely lends it  credibility. But mostly we are interested in the long-term memory this process has and its implementation in finance. In "serious" mathematics, it has been applied several times over – the associated (and applied) Hurst ("H") exponent has an interesting story behind it. A long time ago, guy called Hurst wanted to know what kind of cycles the River Nile would have to better design water reservoirs. He designed an approach to estimate the memory characteristics. Since then, the same approach has been applied in financial markets, and the associated "H" parameter makes the typical random walk (in continuous time, known as "Brownian Motion") more general, allowing for different types of behavior to occur. This, and the fact we also incorporate jump into it, which are notoriously themselves hard to estimate from real exchange data, allows us to approach another important strand of research with far reaching consequences on say option pricing. The better one is able to catch those statistical features, with more and more advanced methods, the more precise estimates for valuation of risk one is able to get. We already released one trading template with Hurst exponen in that, so one can see probably now why it might matter and be also valuable in this framework. This was the real short story behind this... More text and explanations are upcoming in blog-posts and articles, and this will likely start our academic collaboration with universities.
And here are some examples of "Good, Bad, and the Ugly" (of automated trading) for you to help in the development process!

@taos・79 ☯️ This week's release will be split into two parts so as to provide sufficient time to finalize and fully test the optimized simulator/validator communication; today we will push and deploy only validator changes so not requiring to restart the simulation more frequently than needed, with the simulator side updates planned for deployment on Friday:

**Validator Update (Today)**:
* **Synapse Compression Refinement** : Following further testing and exploration to seek additional optimizations to the state publishing process by validators, the compression mechanism and format is adjusted in order to reduce the time taken in preparation, as well as the size of the published state data.  **This change requires all miners to update to the latest package version today between 15:00 UTC (code push) and 17:00 UTC (deployment)**

**Simulator Updates (Friday)**:
* **Simulator Model Adjustments** : We continue to refine the parameters related to the interaction between the new mixed fractional Brownian motion and the background agents, further improving the realism of the market momentums and other key behavioural matters.
* **Simulator<->Validator Communication Optimization** : This update is nearing completion with finalization being the reason for delaying the simulator update deployment; this is targeted at providing a more significant reduction in the time taken at each miner query round by eliminating delays due to GIL locks and state parsing & restructuring.  The expected result is a decent improvement in the simulation progression rate, an important consideration for a number of reasons, chief among which is the ability to produce a larger quantity of data and improve continuity of scoring results.

**Code will be pushed to the repository at ~15:00 UTC.**  Deployment to our validator will be executed ~2H following the push.

Updating again on some of the ongoing projects:

* **Additional Background Agent Types & Models** : While the somewhat smaller tweaks and additions to simulator configuration deployed recently bring us closer to more realistic, interesting and tradeable markets, advanced extensions which produce new conditions reflecting the most critical real-world scenarios in terms of risk management have meanwhile been under continuous research and development.  The latest project centres around the use of an established model applying principles from physics to financial markets, and is expected to enable to generate conditions which much more closely simulate the "bubbles" and "bursts" which are so important to the study of risk in real markets.  This research does take time, mostly due to the complex interactions between the different background model agents and the miner agents, but has seen good progress through the use of novel, conceptually consistent mechanisms to coordinate agent behaviour.
* **Simulation Checkpointing** : The ability to resume stopped simulations has been one of the features intended to be included in the simulator for some time already as this allows to deploy updates without interruption and recover from failures without requiring to start a new simulation; since now at a stage where it makes sense to proceed with this development and given that it can be achieved as an extension of the state communication optimization, the implementation is now underway. We hope to complete this feature in the next 2-3 weeks.
* **Testing, Reporting & Analysis** : We consistently internally expand and refine the tools used in the testing of simulation configurations as well as monitoring and analysis of the subnet data to better support the tuning of market parameters, study of AI agent behaviour and detection and diagnosis of issues.  Several upgrades and refinements enabling more extensive use of the replay tool in creating realistic testing environments are being utilized internally, and some outputs from the reporting and analysis process will start to be shared over the coming weeks. 
* **Dashboard Upgrade** : A completely custom rework of the monitoring dashboard has been in production for a while, with the aim of providing a smoother, more intuitive and interactive experience for those interested in observing our simulated markets and the activities of the agents participating therein.  Progress on this is ongoing, with the first interactive feature enabling more detailed inspection of historical orderbook states in testing while the next feature is under development.
